ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DEREGULATION OF TAXI FARES


    1. Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, with the deregulation of taxi fares, (a) how the consumer will be protected; (b) how the taxi fare increases will be distributed; and (c) how much of each dollar of taxi fare goes to the taxi company, the various taxes (Certificate of Entitlement, import tax, registration fee, Electronic Road Pricing charges, etc), diesel and the driver.

    2. Mr J B Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology whether the proposed increase in taxi fares has been made solely at the request of the companies that operate the taxi services or because the taxi drivers themselves have been complaining that they are not earning enough from the present fares.

    The Minister for Communications and Information Technology (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, Members of this House will recall that the Public Transport Council (PTC) deregulated taxi fares in September 1998. This means that taxi companies now have autonomy to set taxi fares without needing to seek approval from the PTC. They now have more flexibility to introduce differentiated and niche services and to respond more quickly to changes in the environment through differential pricing strategies. The aim was to allow the forces of demand and supply to determine the pricing of taxi services that would optimise the utilisation of the taxi fleet. With deregulation, taxi companies have to consider carefully and individually decide on fare revisions based on their pricing strategy and supply-demand considerations.

Column: 501



    Taxi companies have to price their services at a fair level, taking into consideration, among other factors, the demand for their services, cost of providing the services, earnings of taxi drivers, competition from other taxi companies and other modes of transport, the need to generate adequate returns to pay for vehicle replacement, and to invest in expansion and upgrading. Commuters are in the best position to decide whether taxi fares are set too high or too low. If taxi fares are set too high, the demand will drop and taxi companies will not be able to operate their business profitably. Conversely, if fares are set too low, supply will not be able to match demand and service standards will drop.

    The deregulation of taxi fares therefore serves to optimise the utilisation of resources in meeting the demand for taxi services. Commuters stand to gain as it ensures that the pricing of taxi services is competitive.

    With fare deregulation, how each dollar of the taxi fare is distributed is determined by the taxi companies. We can expect that, to retain drivers in this highly competitive and tight labour market, taxi companies will have to enable their drivers to earn a decent income.

CERTIFICATE OF ENTITLEMENTS
(Review of categorisation)


    3. Dr Jennifer Lee asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, in view of the trend that has emerged from the converging of Certificate of Entitlement prices, if his Ministry will reconsider and review the categorisation of COEs, in order to preserve and support a system in which car buyers will have more choices and the ability to opt for smaller capacity cars.

    The Minister of State for Communications and Information Technology (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for Communications and Information Technology): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the

Column: 502

Clerk of Parliament to distribute the handout? [Copies of handout distributed to hon. Members].

    Sir, the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) categories for small and medium-sized cars were merged into one category, Category A, in May 1999, following a review by the Government Parliamentary Committee. The Committee had noted that ideally, there should only be one category of COEs, and recommended the merger of the two COE categories to also address the concern that the COE quota for small cars was declining while their COE prices were not greatly different from those for medium-sized cars.

    The merger of the two categories to form a larger quota has helped to stabilise COE prices. This does not however mean that the COE for smaller cars will be cheaper than that for bigger cars, because price is a function of demand and supply. Latest prices for Category B COEs for cars more than 1,600 cc against that for Category A COEs for cars up to 1,600 cc bear this out. The COE price of Category A is close to and sometimes higher than that of Category B. This is in spite of the fact that the monthly quota for Category A, as it stands now, is 2,617, which is more than twice the size of the quota for Category B, which is 1,153.

    Sir, combining the former COE Categories 1 and 2 into one category for all cars with engine capacity up to 1,600 cc has given car buyers greater flexibility to decide what cars to buy based on affordability. The fact that more choose to buy at the higher cc end of this category reflects consumer preference for such cars. This is notwithstanding the fact that there are other cheaper, smaller cc models in the category which are more affordable. As a matter of fact, the prices of some small cars have not changed much, compared to the first quarter of 1999 before the two COE categories were merged. I have distributed to Members some data to show the comparison of car prices to illustrate what I mean. If you look at Table 1, generally, the prices for small cars are lower than prices for medium-sized cars. When you look at Table 3, comparing the

Column: 503

car prices, say, for small cars before and after the merger, you can see that the changes are not much. Some have gone up, some have come down. The reality is that car buyers have been able to benefit from the merger of the two categories and they are exercising their preferred decision. More of them appear to be opting for the bigger, though slightly more expensive models, rather than the cheapest models within the same COE category.

    On the part of motor dealers, they have responded to the change in demand pattern by adjusting the range and numbers of car models they import for the Singapore market. The decision to bring in fewer small car models is a reflection of the shrinking demand for smaller cars, even though such cars are still, as I have said earlier, generally cheaper and hence more affordable than the bigger cars.

    Owning a car is not a basic need. There is no reason why Government should intervene and arbitrarily decide on the market mix of the car population in Singapore. We should not influence the type of cars buyers should choose. It is best left to car buyers how much they are willing to pay for a COE and what type of cars they want to purchase. From the land transport point of view, all cars, regardless of the size of their engine capacity, occupy the same amount of road space when moving. Hence, traffic engineers have assigned all cars the same Passenger Car Unit (PCU) rating of 1. It is not the intent of the COE scheme to address the social issue of price progressivity. This issue is addressed through the Additional Registration Fee (ARF) and customs duty which are pegged to the Open Market Value (OMV) of the vehicle, and the road tax structure which is based on the engine capacity.

    Looking at the current COE trends, some have expressed the view that Government should move towards merging all car categories into one broad category. The COE categories were restructured just over a year ago. We will be introducing open bidding for COEs later this year. It is best that we let the system stabilise and

Column: 504

observe the price trends of COEs and consumer preferences. Hence, the Government has no plans at this stage to merge the two car categories into a single category.

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Sir, I would just simply like to ask the Minister of State that, albeit that cars are not a basic need, they do form a very real part of the aspirations of many Singaporeans and, therefore, the LTA, as it further studies refinements and hopefully enhancements from the public point of view, takes due consideration that it tries not to contribute more to the very real and growing feeling among ordinary Singaporeans that more and more things are getting out of reach of the little guy and of young people starting out in their careers.

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, we understand that the aspiration to own cars is there and, of course, subject to the congestion objective, the Government will try to help Singaporeans fulfill their aspiration. As I said, at the moment, there is progressivity also in the ARF and the road tax, and the COE is not intended to accentuate that progressivity. But what we can do is wherever we can, subject to congestion level, we will try to give more COEs and that will lower the COE prices.

Column: 504

FOREIGN DOMESTIC WORKERS
(Complaints on ill-treatment and abuse)


    4. Mr Thomas Thomas asked the Minister for Manpower if he will give figures of complaints received for the last two years on ill-treatment and abuse of foreign domestic workers in Singapore and state the actions taken by the authorities in addressing these complaints.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1997, the Singapore Police Force recorded 157 substantiated cases of foreign domestic worker abuse. In 1998, the number of substantiated abuse cases reported by foreign domestic workers dropped to 89 cases and in 1999, it fell further to 82 cases.

Column: 505



    Members will recall that in May 1998, the Penal Code was amended to enhance penalties by 1.5 times for offences committed against foreign domestic workers by the employer or members of the employer's household. This appeared to have helped to reduce the number of cases of foreign domestic worker abuse.

    There are more than 100,000 foreign domestic workers working in Singapore. The number of cases of abuse or ill treatment is only a small proportion of the total number of foreign domestic workers working here. The vast majority of foreign domestic workers in Singapore are generally well-treated and enjoy a happy and rewarding working relationship with their employers. This is evident from the fact that Singapore continues to attract an increasing number of foreign domestic workers and many of them have in fact decided to extend their work permits beyond the normal two-year term.

    Mr Thomas Thomas (Nominated Member): I would just like to ask the Minister: is there a problem with domestic maids not complying with the terms of their work permit and therefore we have to send them off? What I am saying is that since the problem with employers is so small, what about the problems of the domestic maids themselves? Are there any significant problems?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, I believe that the Member is referring to the group of foreign domestic workers who either take off from their employer's household and moonlight on their own in other occupations or are deployed by the employer to work in some other occupations. Let me assure the Member that while this problem exists and that, from time to time, my Ministry's enforcement officers come across such cases and take action against them, both employers and employees, the number of cases is small. It is not a growing problem. We are continuing to educate employers of foreign domestic workers on their responsibility, not only on the welfare part about treating the foreign domestic workers well

Column: 506

and caring for them, but also to remind employers that they should not deploy them to work outside the household, whether it is to help out the employer in the hawker stall or in the provision shop in the neighbourhood. Such duties are obviously not part of the domestic duties of the foreign domestic worker and employers should refrain from sending their foreign domestic workers to work in such occupations. If they do and if they are caught, they face fairly severe penalties.

Column: 506

NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
(Establishment)


    5. Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad asked the Minister for Manpower what is the current status of the proposed establishment of the National Institute on Occupational Safety and Health.

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, a National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health was one of the proposals of the Manpower21 Report.

    Currently, my Ministry's Occupational Safety and Health (Training and Promotion) Centre carries out training in occupational safety and health (OSH) as well as implements programmes to promote OSH awareness. It conducts a wide range of training courses for managers, professionals, supervisors and workers. It also organises safety campaigns, seminars and workshops to promote safety and health in factories. We also have well-established private sector safety consultants to help companies improve their safety performance.

    In the case of research and development, we should tap the results of work by institutions in developed countries which are more advanced in OSH R&D. If there is a need to carry out researches on our own occupational safety and health issues, we can do that in collaboration with our institutions of higher learning, perhaps with funding from National Science and Technology Board. In other words, the major features of a National Institute of

Column: 507

Occupational Safety and Health are already being addressed by the existing industrial safety framework. Hence we do not see an urgent need to establish an Institute on Occupational Safety and Health at this juncture. However, we will review the need for such an institute sometime in future.

Column: 507

COMMODITIES TRADING FIRMS
(Regulation)


    6. Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if his Ministry has any plans to curb unregulated commodities trading firms that advertise in the newspapers for job applicants and subsequently apply strong arm tactics on the respondents to invest in commodities trading.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, trading in commodities futures is regulated under the Commodities Futures Act. Currently, this Act covers only commodities that are traded on the Singapore Commodity Exchange (SICOM), namely, rubber and coffee.

    Firms that trade in other commodities are not regulated. As Mr Ong and other Members of the House have pointed out, some of these firms, commonly known as bucket shops, have enticed the public to open trading accounts with them. They engage in trading practices that are against the interest of investors.

    MTI will be proposing amendments to the Commodities Futures Act to extend the Act to cover all commodities and associated derivatives, and to require any firm that wishes to trade in commodities to be licensed. However, to ensure that, obviously, bona fide traders are not inconvenienced, several categories of traders (other than those trading in rubber and coffee) will be exempted from the licensing requirement. These categories will include principal-to-principal traders, over-the-counter traders and banks. The proposed amendments will help to stamp out bucket shops, without overly inconveniencing bona fide traders. In drafting the

Column: 508

new legislation, we welcome the views of all Members of the House and the public.

    Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan (Nominated Member): Sir, as part of the review of the legislation, would the Minister also consider legislating a cooling off period from the date of signing the agreement, so that a prospective investor will have more time to consider his intentions before activating the investment account?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, we can consider such a provision. But we have got to look at it from all angles to see whether it sets a precedent for other transactions which may become a problem. But we will consider it.

Column: 508

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Enhanced incentives for first-time buyers)


    7. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry will further enhance incentives for first-time buyers of Housing and Development Board flats so as to assist young couples start their homes and families earlier.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB has several schemes to assist young couples to start their homes and families earlier. Firstly, HDB flats are sold at subsidised prices to ensure that they are affordable to young couples. Next, HDB provides mortgage financing at concessionary interest rates to first-timers. HDB flat buyers can make use of their CPF savings to pay the 20% downpayment.

    HDB also has a Fiance/Fiancee Scheme whereby young couples intending to get married can apply for new HDB flats before their marriage. For those on the Registration for Flat System, HDB allocates more flats to first-timers compared to upgraders, to enable the former to start up their homes earlier. Today, first-timers can select their HDB flats within one to one and a half years

Column: 509

from the date of application. If they select completed flats, they can take possession of the flats within a few months from selection.

    Furthermore, first-time purchasers can buy resale flats or Executive Condominiums with the CPF Housing Grant Scheme. The grant of $30,000 to $40,000 will help to defray the initial cost of purchase of their resale flats or Executive Condominiums.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether he would consider raising the loan ceiling for first-time buyers from 80% to 90%, similar to the existing schemes available for joint selection multi-tier family and confirmed Government officers?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, the requirement of 80% is a prudent practice to ensure that buyers will buy flats within their affordability. We also have schemes to help low-income families to obtain a bigger mortgage financing. For ordinary first-timers, it is best that they stick to the 20% deposit. But if they have financial difficulty, they can always appeal to their MPs and we will look at the case on its own merit.

    Dr Lily Neo: Sir, on the question of affordability, may I inform the Minister of State that, in fact, there are already affordability criteria, such as maximum quantum and maximum repayment period. The criteria are already in place. What is the worry on that?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, the credit assessment that we have is to ensure that people buy flats within their affordability. The 20% downpayment is also prudent market practice in the private sector, and this policy is to make sure that people have enough savings before they actually start thinking of buying a flat. So I think it is quite a prudent approach.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Demand and supply)


    8. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the status of planned and actual demand and supply of Housing and Development Board flats from 1998 to 2000; (b) how many HDB building project tenders were called in 1999 and the first quarter of 2000 and not awarded till to date; and (c) what is the waiting time for both new flat applicants and upgraders.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB received 8,800 and 9,700 Registration for Flats System applications in 1998 and 1999 respectively, and an average of about 1,200 applications per month during the first five months of this year. As a result, the queue length for HDB flats has declined to about 37,000 as at 31st May 2000, compared to a peak of about 146,000 in the year 1996/1997. The shorter queue has enabled HDB to reduce the waiting time to about 1 to 1.5 years for first-timer applicants, and to about 3 to 4 years for upgrader applicants.

    In view of the lower demand for new HDB flats, HDB has reduced its building programme from about 28,000 units in 1998 to 22,000 units in 1999. It is planning for a further reduction of the building programme for this year. Nonetheless, the decline in HDB building works will not have a significant impact on the construction sector as work on other public buildings is projected to increase this year.

    On the status of HDB tenders, HDB called tender for 32 building contracts in 1999 and 9 building contracts in the first quarter of 2000. Of these, 14 contracts are still under evaluation, and the majority of which will be awarded between June and October this year.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Sembawang): Sir, may I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary how many construction firms working on

Column: 511

existing contracts have been asked by HDB to slow down their programmes, and whether the HDB will compensate the contractors if these construction works are slowed down?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, I am not aware that HDB has asked any existing contractors to slow down the existing building programme. What HDB has done is to evaluate the 14 contracts that will be awarded between now and October this year. In view of the reduced demand for HDB flats, HDB is now looking at the tenders that are going to the market, and those which we have called for tenders but not yet awarded.

    As regards compensation, for those tenders which are under the design and build category, HDB can consider it if contractors come to us and say, "You have called for tenders. We have put in effort for the tender and now you have decided either to defer or cancel it altogether." But so far, no contractor has come to us and asked for compensation.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin: Sir, may I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether the HDB is prepared to relax the so-called offer of rejected flats for walk-in selection? There are new applicants for certain flats. Sometimes there are rejections. These flats are normally pooled and put up in advertisements for the next allocation. Can we open it up earlier so that applicants can walk in to select flats?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, we can consider that proposal.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Purchase and rental)


    9. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board will (i) allow single persons to purchase new 4-room flats; (ii) allow HDB lessees (within the 5-year occupation period) to downgrade to 3- or 4-room flats; and (iii) increase the income ceiling for rental flats to $1,000.

Column: 512



    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, as a general policy, our public housing programme requires flat applicants to form a family nucleus to qualify for the purchase of a new flat from HDB. This is in line with the philosophy that the family is the basic building block of a strong and stable society.

    However, to meet the housing needs of some Singaporeans who remain single and would like to live on their own, the HDB has in place two schemes, namely, the Single Singapore Citizen Scheme and the Joint Singles Scheme. Under the Single Singapore Citizen Scheme, singles who are 35 years and above can buy resale 3-room or smaller flats located outside the urban areas. The 3-room flats provide more than sufficient space for singles who live on their own.

    Under the Joint Singles Scheme, two eligible single citizens can jointly purchase resale flats of any size anywhere in Singapore. The CPF Housing Grant Scheme is also open to first-timer single applicants who are 35 years or more. Today, the grant is $11,000 under the Single Singapore Citizen Scheme and double that, $22,000, under the Joint Singles Scheme.

    Sir, as there are sufficient avenues to meet the housing needs of singles, I think for now there is no need to allow singles to purchase new 4-room flats.

    Dr Teo also asked about downgrading during the first 5-year occupation period. In general, HDB requires lessees to occupy their flats for at least five years before they can sell them in the open market. This is to deter speculation on HDB flats, which are heavily subsidized.

    However, there are two options available to HDB lessees if they need, for whatever reasons, to downgrade to smaller flats within the 5-year occupation period. First, they can surrender their existing flat to HDB and then purchase a resale flat from the open market; or they can mutually exchange their existing flat with another lessee, provided both parties have

Column: 513

completed a minimum 1-year occupation period and meet the requirements of the scheme.

    Dr Teo also asked about raising the income ceiling for rental flats. Sir, HDB reviews the income ceiling regularly to take into account changes in household incomes. In the case of rental flats, raising the ceiling from the current $800 per month to $1,000 per month may be against the Government's objective to help as many Singaporeans as possible become home owners. Nevertheless, I would like to assure the House that HDB does exercise flexibility to allow families with incomes exceeding $800 per month to rent HDB flats at subsidized rental if there are mitigating circumstances. HDB also has several assistance schemes, such as Sale of Flats to Sitting Tenants, Sale of 3-Room Buy Back Flats and Rent and Purchase Scheme, to help the lower income groups to own HDB flats.

Column: 513

WORKERS FROM LOWER-INCOME GROUP
(Training grants)


    10. Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan asked the Minister for Manpower if his Ministry has any plans to provide further incentives to workers from the lower-income group to enrol for training courses to upgrade their skills, for example, by giving an appropriate level of training grants directly to these workers.

    The Minister of State for Manpower (Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe) (for the Minister for Manpower): Sir, worker training is critical for our economic competitiveness and successful transformation into a knowledge-based economy. With economic restructuring, the types of jobs available and the skills needed to perform these jobs will continue to change. These new jobs will require higher skills. For Singaporeans, especially lower income and less educated workers, continual skills upgrading is the key to ensuring employability and enhancing incomes.

Column: 514



    Hence, the Government has recently committed additional funds to motivate and facilitate skills upgrading. In February this year, my Ministry established a $200 million Manpower Development Assistance Scheme (MDAS) to support manpower development initiatives over the next five years. Of the $200 million, $90 million has been set aside for the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP), aimed at retraining lower skilled workers. This is in addition to the $50 million committed to the programme in 1998. Under the SRP, we aim to provide training for 100,000 workers over five years. Currently, we have about 26,000 workers who have completed or are undergoing SRP training.     In 1966, the Government sent me to study Development Economics in Williams College in the US. It was a special course for officials from developing countries. I was then a young officer working in the Economic Planning Unit.

    Different people will have different definitions of a good government. My own criteria for a good government are:

Test of Government

    The true strength of a government is revealed when it is put through the most severe crisis. This Government has been put through one in the recent Asian financial crisis. The financial storm devastated the economies of South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia, but left Singapore relatively unscathed.

    Just consider the damage to these economies in 1998.

    South Korea's economy shrank by 6.7%.

    Thailand's economy shrank by 10.2%, Malaysia's by 7.4%, and Indonesia's by a massive 13%.

    In contrast, Singapore avoided a contraction in 1998. Our economy still grew, if only by 0.4%.

    Suppose we had not managed our economy well. It could easily have shrunk by 5%. This would have taken off $9.5 billion (at current prices) from our GDP. Divide this by a population of 3 million and you will get a loss of $3,166 per person. This is an indication of the price each Singaporean pays if we had not managed our economy well.

    In contrast, what was the total annual salary for all political office-holders in 1998? About $28 million.

    What is the total salary increase we are proposing for political office-holders? About $6 million. With the salary revision, the annual salaries of all political office-holders, that is my Government, will rise from $28 million currently to $34 million. Is this a lot of money when compared with the $9.5 billion damage to the economy that could have been inflicted by the Asian

Column: 552

financial crisis? Is $34 million a lot of money when they amount to only 0.024% of our GDP of $144 billion (at current prices)?

    Let me put it simply: the damage we had prevented to the economy from the Asian financial crisis is more than enough to pay the Ministers and the other political office-holders for the rest of their political lives and in fact over many lifetimes!

    The Asian financial crisis has distinguished us from the other regional economies. Recently, an American asked the US Ambassador to Singapore, Mr Steven Green, on the Internet: "Why was Singapore affected less than the region during the economic crisis?"

    His reply: "In one word, it is management. Singaporeans are very fortunate to have a government that is very well-managed, very far-sighted and willing to embrace change."

    Foreign governments and investors have noted our strengths in the crisis. Our ability to withstand the crisis has increased confidence in Singapore. This is obvious from my many meetings with foreign investors and leaders both in Singapore and abroad. We are going to see more foreign investments come in. This means more jobs and better jobs.

    Let us put the salaries of Ministers in their proper perspective. A million dollars for a Minister seems a lot when compared to the salary of a worker. But $34 million for all the Ministers and political office-holders, that is the cost of government, is a tiny drop when compared to the increase in GDP that a good government can produce. For every 1% growth, the GDP increases by $1.4 billion.

Good People for Good Government

    So how do we produce a good government? Get the best to serve the country.

    A good government does not come naturally. It must be systematically created through the active recruitment of good and able people. You cannot just

Column: 553

leave it to the electoral process to throw up a good government. If the present ruling party is not able to persuade some of the best people to enter politics, you will have only weak men and women to choose from to form a government.

    After every election, we immediately look for new candidates for the next election (we do not wait until the election is about to come) - from the civil service, SAF, Police, statutory boards, GLCs, the professions and the private sector. In other words, all over Singapore. Since the last GE, we have already invited nearly 250 Singaporeans in their late 20s to mid-40s for tea sessions. By the time of the next GE, we would have met 400 to 500 potential candidates. Out of them, we hope to find 15 to 20 with these 5 "Cs" qualities. These are the 5 "Cs" which a potential candidate must have (not your usual 5 "Cs" but my 5 "Cs"):

    (1) Capability: Does he have a record of good performance? Does he have the potential to become an office-holder? Does he have good judgment? Does he have leadership qualities?

    (2) Character: Does he have character flaws? Is he able to get on with people and motivate them?

    (3) Compassion: Has he done things for others beyond his own family? Does he care for others?

    (4) Conviction: What does he believe in? What does he want to achieve in life? What motivates him? Why does he want to be an MP or a Minister?

    (5) Commitment: Is he loyal to his friends? Will he stay the course? Will he fight when the chips are down?

    If we assess that a person is interested only in politics as a career move, he will not be chosen as a candidate. If he is attracted only by the pay, he will not be selected as a Minister. But that does not mean we should not pay a Minister what he is worth. We are targeting the top

Column: 554

people to be Ministers. They are high-income earners or will be in their non-political careers. We will have to pay them a competitive, market-based salary so that pay will not be an obstacle discouraging them from entering politics.

    Professor Joseph Nye, Dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, made the same point in a talk in Singapore last year. He said:

    "Singapore is very wise. You need to attract good people into government, and paying high salaries reduces the incentive for corruption."



    On his point on corruption, Singapore's policy of paying our public officials market-based wages has helped us create a corruption-free environment. Transparency International, an NGO dedicated to fighting corruption worldwide, has consistently ranked Singapore within the top ten least corrupt countries in the world, since its index was first published in 1995. Among Asian countries, we are rated the least corrupt.

    Professor Nye added that the high salaries also helped "lateral entries" from the private sector into government. He said that this was important in a modern economy with a complex, fast-paced financial sector, as government decision-makers would need the inputs of private sector practitioners.

    Professor Nye was right about lateral transfers. When we identify a suitable young man (or woman) with the potential to be a Minister, we have to persuade him to give up his bright prospects in the private sector for an uncertain future in politics. Benchmarking Ministers' salaries to what the best in the private sector earns, makes it easier for us to get some of the best people to become Ministers.

    Some may argue that you do not have to pay so much to get people to join the public sector or become Ministers, and that there will always be people who want to become Ministers or civil servants. Quite right, if you think in terms of quantity, not quality.

Column: 555



    The Economist in an article in its issue of 8th May 1999 on "The Politics of Envy" asked: "Why do governments systematically underpay their top people?" And answered that it is the tendency to think in terms of quantity, not quality.

    Andrew Oswald, an economist at Warwick University, was quoted in the same article:

    "Governments can set low pay and still get workers. It is the quality that will adjust. I doubt whether western democracies have fully grasped this. Governments still tend to count the warm bodies applying for occupations."

    But not this Government. It goes for quality, not merely warm bodies, and certainly not seat-warmers. That is why we have performance bonuses for political office-holders, one of the few countries in the world to do so. Ministers are paid in accordance with their performance.     We also insist on self-renewal. MPs and Ministers, even though they are performing well, will at the right time, have to make way for younger people.

    In future, Permanent Secretaries too, even if they are good, will have to make way for younger people. Otherwise, younger people with high potential will not stay long enough to become Permanent Secretaries.

Column: 556



Timing of Salary Revision

    Some MPs have told me that while they support the salary revision for the public sector, they are concerned about the timing because the CPF cut has not yet been fully restored.

    There are two reasons why we are proceeding with the salary revision now.

    First, in November 1994, when we debated the White Paper on Competitive Salaries for Competent and Honest Government, we said that the salary benchmarks would be reviewed in five years' time.

    Second, the gap between private sector and public sector pay has become a gulf since the start of the Asian financial crisis. This is because the Government froze the salaries of Ministers and top civil servants during the crisis. This was despite the fact that the salaries were due for upward revision. For example, the private sector benchmark for Ministers' salaries at Staff Grade 1 had increased by 13% in 1998 and 29% in 1999. Not to adjust the Ministers' and civil servants' pay now when we have emerged from the crisis and resumed strong growth, and especially when it is fully justified by the private sector benchmarks, is to fall into a state of paralysis experienced by governments elsewhere when they faced the issue of public sector pay revision. Because they were unable to keep the salaries competitive vis-a-vis the private sector, inevitably, their countries saw a decline in the quality of people wanting to be MPs, Ministers, judges and civil servants.

    We are not, however, insensitive to workers' feelings and public sentiments. Because the CPF cut has not been fully restored, we are not restoring immediately the pay of Ministers and top civil servants to the private sector benchmark for Staff Grade I, but phasing it in over three years. These office-holders will receive only 80% of the benchmark in the first year. The basic monthly salary for

Column: 557

Ministers will therefore increase by only 0.3% this year. With bonuses, the annual increase for Ministers will be a modest 12%.

Today's Realities

    In debating the salary revisions, let me remind you of some realities we cannot run away from.

    First, we are seeing a global convergence in the pay of top executives. Globalisation and technological advances in transportation and communication have led to increasing mobility of this group of people. They are able to move easily around the world in search of the best employment opportunities. If they do not get internationally competitive remuneration in their country, they can easily uproot for other more favourable opportunities in another country. Companies are therefore increasingly pressured to pay internationally competitive salaries for top executives, regardless in which country they operate.

    Second, our job of retaining talents is made more difficult because Singaporeans, with their proficiency in English and high competence, are mobile and in great international demand. American universities and MNCs regularly cream off our scholars and bright students who study in the US.

    Third, we must make a rapid transition to a knowledge-based economy. We have done the easier parts like building infrastructure, putting in place a business-friendly environment, and training our workers for skilled jobs. The next phase is much more difficult. We have to create new products and services ourselves and not merely add value to other people's products. With globalization and the IT revolution, competition has heightened. It is a new ball game altogether.

    Overall, what all this means is that the wages of top private sector talents in Singapore will face significant upward pressure in the years to come. Companies in Singapore will have to pay their top

Column: 558

local executives internationally competitive salaries to retain them. Certainly, they have to pay internationally competitive salaries for foreign talents. But let me add here that expatriates are excluded from the calculation of the salary benchmarks.

    The Government has no choice but to match these upward trends in private sector pay in order to attract its fair share of talents. But the Government does not intend to be a price-setter. It will not lead the pace of pay revision in Singapore. It will only be a price-taker. We will only respond to the trends in the private sector, with a lag of one year, to ensure that public sector pay remains competitive.

    Another reality we cannot escape from is the widening income gap between the top and bottom earners. In every society, there will be a bottom 10% and a top 10% of wage earners. The Government cannot artificially reduce the income gap between these two segments of the population by forcing upwards the salaries of the bottom 10%, or forcing downwards the salaries of the top 10%. This is a market economy, not a command economy. What the Government will do, however, is to ensure that all Singaporeans have an equal opportunity to make it to the top 10%. At the same time, we will help the relatively poor to ensure that they also benefit from the general increase in prosperity. The Government has already put in place a system of subsidies for education, housing and health. It has also implemented several assets-enhancement programmes. We will continue to help the lower-income Singaporeans increase their assets, as well as improve their earning capacity through training and skills upgrading. We will give them hope through investments in their children's education and future.

Conclusion

    As Prime Minister, I have travelled widely and seen many governments at work. Our Ministers can stand their own against most of their counterparts elsewhere. We have a Cabinet Singapore can be proud of.

Column: 559



    My most urgent job now is to make sure that there will be a successor team which can manage Singapore's complex economy in an increasingly competitive global environment, and which also understands the concerns of the man-in-the-street. I can build up this team only if we are able to persuade good men and women into politics.

    The difficulty here is that a political career is not the natural or first choice of most able Singaporeans. Other major advanced countries too, like the US, face the same problem.

    We have to overcome this problem. Singapore has left behind the revolutionary stage where leaders emerged to lead a historic movement with little thought of pay. We are in a steady state of development where fortunes can be made in the buzz of the private sector. There is much excitement in the new world of dotcoms, financial services, life sciences and R&D. Most able Singaporeans prefer to seek fulfilment in these challenges rather than in politics. If we fail to get a group of these bright, able and honest Singaporeans to form the political core of Singapore, then over time, the standard of government will go down, and Singapore will crumble.

    Singapore is vulnerable. It does not have any natural resources except our people. Our people have been fortunate to be led by a good and competent Government since 1959. It will be very shortsighted and costly for Singaporeans if we grudge good Ministers their due, and settle for lesser men in Government in the future.

    I have gone through the proposed revisions to public sector salaries and salary benchmarks thoroughly. I am satisfied that they are fair. I do not think they are generous, given the Ministers' huge responsibilities and impact on our people's lives. I want the right people to do these jobs. And so should you.

    That Ministers' pay is a source of envy for some people is not necessarily bad. We are more likely to recruit good Ministers this way. I would be extremely

Column: 560

worried if it were the reverse. If Ministers envy the pay of their counterparts in the private sector, that is the first step towards corruption.

    Several MPs have advised me that we must deal with the emotional reaction of Singaporeans over the salary revision. They themselves support the market-based salaries but are concerned that the man-in-the-street will not understand why Ministers have to be paid high salaries. I understand these emotions. But I have faith in the judgment and rationality of Singaporeans. I have no doubt that some Singaporeans will react emotionally and will not accept our arguments. But I believe most Singaporeans will listen to the logic and make a rational decision. They have always done so. A rational and practical approach to problems has always been Singapore's hallmark. Otherwise, Singapore will not be where it is today.

    To conclude, let me go back to my Williams College days. I have often wondered what has happened to my classmates.

    What has happened to my Ethiopian friend, who already had six children at Williams College? He was a high official in the government of the late deposed Emperor Haile Selassie.

    As for my Yugoslav friend from Croatia, I wonder whether his children had to fight fellow Yugoslavs to become Croatians?

    What about the Pakistani official from East Pakistan who became a Bangladeshi? His government house overlooking the port of Chittagong was shelled during the war.

    Fortunately, there were other classmates who have done well, retiring in high government positions. But their countries have not lived up to their dreams when they were young men at Williams College, eager to learn and eager to put into practice what they had learnt.

    The real lesson for me from Williams College was: without a good government,

Column: 561

all the good theories of economic development count for nothing. Countries with weak or bad governments will go downhill, suffer internal strife and may even break up. They will not be able to deliver a high standard of living for their people. And when a country goes down, it is not the able people who will suffer most. It is the man-in-the-street. They are the people who cannot migrate easily. They are the ones who need a good government most.

    So ask yourself, "Where will Singapore be 30 years from now? What type of government will produce you a safe, stable and prosperous Singapore?"

    Let me help you answer the questions by giving you some simple arithmetic.

    First, the wage cost of all the political office-holders will be $34 million after this pay revision. There are three million Singaporeans. What is the cost of Government per capita? $11 per year or about five plates of "char kway teow" per Singaporean.

    Second, in 1995, the Government made a contribution of $200 into the CPF account of all Singaporeans aged 21 and above and an additional pro-rated contribution of up to $300 to those who had contributed $750 themselves to their CPF account. The total amount paid out was about $800 million. What was the pay-out per Singaporean? $270, if we divide it by a population of three million.

    We can do more such CPF top-ups in future, provided we have good growth. $11 per capita per year for a Government that can produce good economic growth and give you $270, even if it is once in five years, is surely good value for money.

    Summing up, it is wrong to focus on the individual pay of Ministers in isolation. He is only a member of a team. You should focus on the cost of my Government and the benefits and consequences of having that Government. What is the cost of my Government to each Singaporean? Five plates of "char kway teow"! What was the

Column: 562

price each of us would have paid if our economy had shrunk by 5% during the financial crisis? $3,166! And this price is only an example of the huge price you have to pay for a weak or bad government.

    We have put in place a virtuous cycle of good Government, economic growth and benefits for the people. For your own benefit, it is wise for you to strengthen, not break this cycle. [Applause]

    Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, when you do a doctoral thesis, you do not do such a simple correlation that the higher the pay, the more the benefits for the people. Column: 563



    We have had extensive debates before, inside and outside this House, on the issue of the amount that political appointment holders and, in particular, a Minister, should be getting as his salary. Mr Chiam had earlier alluded to the fact that to the average Singaporeans who may not be paid as much, especially to the fair number of Singaporeans who earn less than $24,000 a year, the idea of a Minister getting more than a million dollars is beyond comprehension.

    At first brush, there seems to be a sense of inequity to this. Somehow, many Singaporeans feel that it is not right that there should be such a divide between the masses and a small number of political elite who, as the people's representatives, should reward themselves so handsomely with such salaries.

    Sir, against this thinking, there is a sense that the people have made deep sacrifices, as was acknowledged by the Prime Minister earlier, when the Government decided to cut their CPF contribution following the recent financial crisis. Their CPF contribution has not been fully restored to date and there are constant calls for the Government to restore their CPF contribution to the level before the financial crisis. Therefore, for some, it seems odd that while they are making the sacrifices by taking pay cuts, the political appointment holders and civil servants should be increasing their salaries at this time. Many Singaporeans may feel that the Government should continue to set the example, as Mr Chiam had said earlier, by keeping the salary freeze until such time when CPF contribution has been fully restored to the people and the economy shows robust growth again.

    The Ministerial Statement unfortunately also comes at a time and hot on the heels of the recent spate of announcements of cost increases. These include, for instance, the $2 charge on POSB accounts for those who maintain low deposits, and the recent announcement of revision to water rates, increase in transportation charges, and other private sector led charges.

Column: 564



    At this moment, we know that the recovery of the Singapore economy is rather selective and not across the board. The construction industry is still in the doldrums and many Singaporeans are still unemployed. At my MPS alone, I get many requests from my constituents for help in looking for jobs. They are the ones who have been retrenched and are not so employable on account of age.

    Against the backdrop of the present scenario, many Singaporeans may be asking: how can the Government increase the salary of civil servants and political appointment holders?

    I do not deny, Sir, that the issue of Ministers' salary has always been a very emotive one. For reasons that I shall elaborate later, I support the move by the Government to increase the public sector salary. Let me examine some of the arguments raised against the salary revision.

    First, as was alluded to by Mr Chiam, the inequity argument, ie, the growing gap in income distribution between the top and bottom income earners and the fact that CPF contribution has not been fully restored. Sir, the argument of social inequity is based on the idea of equal misery for all. The argument simply put is this: as long as there is inequality of income distribution and as long as CPF contribution has not been fully restored, political appointment holders, least of all, should be allowed to have salary revision.

    Can this argument be tenable? Against this argument, we have to ask ourselves the kind of society we want to build for Singapore. I do not think for a moment that a country founded on a political philosophy of equal misery for all is going to bring about more wealth for the people in the long term. Let us recognise a basic principle here. We are a market economy where talents and resources are allocated on the basis of pricing. You want the best talent, you must be prepared to pay for the best talent; and by talent, I mean not only people with the ability to run the country well but also the honesty and integrity to run it.

Column: 565



    To the detractors, I have a question. Would you rather pay the political appointment holders a fraction of the salary and have either people without the ability to take charge of our Government and make a mess of Singapore or have people whose only interest in coming to public office is to cream off the system and line their pockets in the process? Let us be honest about it. Talent is in short supply in Singapore. We want to attract the best talents to serve this country. For them, they will have to come out of the comfort zones of their established careers and family for the country. It is indeed a sacrifice for many who have established themselves in their career. They have to make a judgement call by resigning their jobs and serving the country as political appointment holders. We all know that there is no assurance that they will succeed in the long run as political appointment holders, having made the sacrifice. It is therefore quite clear that some sacrifices would be necessary.

    However, to ask them to make near complete sacrifice or even total sacrifice in the service of the country is a very naive thing to do, Mr Chiam. These people have their mortgages to pay, their children to look after and a certain lifestyle to keep. His calculation of $50,000 is a relative thing. To the very poor in the poorest country in the world, your lifestyle would be obscenely rich. I think it is quite inappropriate to just pluck a figure out of thin air and to say that it is appropriate by your standard and your judgement. Let the person who is deemed by the power that be, who is capable of running this country, decide whether or not it is a sacrifice that is worth making and paying at the point in time.

    The answer to the call to political office to serve the country is not a call to priesthood. They are not expected to live the life of an ascetic. Even in Israel, where the country has for years had prime ministers who lived rather ascetic lives, has had to face down two major scandals recently, when their President and former Prime Minister came under investigation

Column: 566

on allegations of corruption. If a salary adjustment is in order, and having lived with a wage freeze for the last three years, why should we begrudge this adjustment?

    We are not a basket case where our people live from hand to mouth. We can afford the salary increase and we want to continue to have people at the top who will be able to give all of us, and not just some Singaporeans, a better life in the new economy. We had a discussion earlier about the issue of growing income disparity between the poor and the rich in Singapore. The question that we have to ask ourselves is whether we want to pay the right people at the top to continue to create wealth for Singapore and to close the income gap in the process. If the answer is yes, should we not be willing to pay the price? The Prime Minister has given us a very lucid illustration earlier and I think the example is very telling.

    Secondly, some Singaporeans, I suspect, may well support the pay increase but would say that it is inappropriate to implement this at this stage with the recent spate of price increases. Sir, with all due respect, I do not think that the two issues are necessarily related. What this argument is tantamount to saying is that because there are price increases, political appointees must not have salary adjustments. Why should the political appointment holders be any different? Are the promoters of this argument saying that wages for all employees should be frozen? Quite clearly, Sir, the argument is non-sequitur.

    Finally, I have heard the argument making its rounds that the political appointment holder who is paid the equivalent of private sector salary may not be able to hold his own in the private sector once he leaves the comfort zone of the public service. This applies to political appointment holders who have never worked in the private sector before. Again, I find this argument rather difficult to follow. Sir, I believe that we have used the salaries of the private sector as a benchmark to allow us to (1) attract and keep those from the private sector with the necessary ability to serve the country;

Column: 567

and, more importantly, (2) to recognise the ability and contribution of political appointment holders who have led the country well.

    It is the cynicism of some Singaporeans on the ability of our political leaders who never really went through the baptism of fire in the private sector that I want to touch on briefly for now. The argument is simply this. We pay Ministers top private sector salaries. Can they really perform to the level of expectation required of the remuneration that they enjoy if they went to the private sector? In other words, would they have earned as much if they actually took on private sector jobs?

    Sir, I believe that to take this line of argument is to confuse the issue. Let me explain. I am a solicitor and I earn an income. I should not be expected to earn the same salary as a doctor if I tried to do the work of a doctor. This is because I am not qualified and, more importantly, may not be suited for the job. The two are not the same. I am paid my salary which may be comparable to a doctor's salary because of what I do as a lawyer. Nobody begrudges the fact that I earn as much as a doctor. By the same token, we use the private sector salary as a benchmark. That does not mean that we should expect all political appointment holders to have the same talent to be a top doctor, lawyer or a banker. What the benchmark does in addition is to provide a basis for valuing the ability of those in the public service. Why should they be valued any less simply because they are in the public sector? Clearly, this approach to pay our public office appointment holders well has been proven right, as was mentioned earlier, because the last round of financial crisis has spared this country of the misery that we have seen in the region. Is this not proof of the quality of the leaders that we have? In other words, the benchmark is arguably our way of remunerating them for the quality of skills that they have brought about in running this country.

    At the end of the day, Sir, we have to ask ourselves: are we prepared to pay the price for top leadership? Is it worth it? I

Column: 568

would say that at least for us, the system is transparent and it is worth every cent of it. We know how much we are paying our public servants; or do we want a system where political appointment holders are paid little, and the true cost of leadership is not known until perhaps the leaders fall and corruption investigations begin? Sir, to my mind, the answer is obvious.

housing and healthcare to the lower-income group, and would continue to invest heavily in education and training, thereby ensuring the employability of the workers.

    A good government will ensure that the children of all Singaporeans, rich or poor, will have equal opportunities to be educated and to be promoted to a better standard of living.

    Good leaders will make the lower-income people feel, at all times, that whenever they encounter difficulties, the Government would be around to lend them a helping hand.

    The politics of meritocracy not only enables the top talents to scale the peak but also continues to provide the lower-income people with the hope and the twilight that they and their children will be led to enjoy a better standard of living.
