Column: 570

CIVIL SERVICE NWC AWARD, PUBLIC SECTOR SALARY REVISIONS,
AND REVIEW OF SALARY BENCHMARKS


    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Cheng San)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, on behalf of the trade unions, I would like to thank the Government for agreeing to credit the unused portions of the annual $350 cap on outpatient subsidy for civil servants who are on the Medisave and Subsidised Outpatient Treatment (MSO) scheme into the Medisave account of the officers. This is a shot in the arm for the unionists' effort to make our medical benefit more portable, and it is a great encouragement to our unionists and gives them more confidence in making representations to the Government on behalf of the workers to review their welfare and benefits.

    I support the DPM's proposal for revision of salaries for civil servants. As we enter the 21st century, the nature and

Column: 571

model of a global economy are undergoing great changes. This is a vast world with blurred boundaries. Compared to the time when we detached ourselves from the British rule some 40 years ago, the Singapore of today has seen a 70-fold increase in our GDP. We have already attained great achievements in social and economic fields. Recently, the Housing and Development Board handed out the 800,000th key to the owner of a brand new HDB flat. 90% of Singaporeans own their own flats. Even among the bottom 10% of our people, some 65% own their 3-room or bigger HDB flats.

    Sir, we have read in various literature and newspapers that different people in different regions, irrespective of their races and nationalities, have some common aspirations. They do not want to be dependent on others. They wish to have their own homes. They also hope that their children have education and everybody craves for the country to be prosperous and the people live in peace and harmony. They hope that their children will grow up healthily, live in a safe country and have jobs that provide them with a stable income.

    Let us take a look at all these hopes and aspirations. We all feel that, as Singaporeans, we should be very proud and happy because many of those things that remain as dreams for the people in many parts of the world have become a reality in Singapore. Most, if not all, of the Singaporeans' dreams have become realities. We must continue to put in our efforts to ensure that our people, especially the younger generation, will continue to enjoy this kind of very good social environment.

    A friend of mine once told me that there are three types of government in the world. The first type of government consists of those who sit back and depend on their national resources to finance the government's spending and eventually squander away all the national wealth. The second type is a government consisting of people who work very hard to create wealth - for themselves. The third type is a government comprising

Column: 572

able people who work hard to create wealth for the country and help the people to enhance their assets and share the fruits of success brought about by the government.

    We cannot find anywhere on the map of the world any other country like the little red dot of Singapore. Yet, our system and our hardworking people have made us outstanding and different. It is only here in Singapore that we have this kind of transparency to discuss the question of how to implement meritocracy for good government to continue to help the country prosper and develop. What we want in this kind of system of transparency is reward based on merit. Because we do not want to be like many other countries in the world which have fallen into the pit of quicksand of money politics. Neither do we want to be a country using the "little above board and plenty under the table" kind of reward system. As a matter of fact, this kind of transparent salary system for our Ministers and civil servants who have sacrificed a lot, is one which can be described as a "win-win" system for both the Ministers and the masses.

    As it is often quoted by the Opposition Member, "After all, the wool still comes from the sheep's back." (meaning in the long run, whatever you are given, you pay for it). However, we must stress that if you want to have the wool, you must also ensure that the sheep can grow with good health. Then only will we have the wool to shear. Let me give you another illustration. If a farmer can rear the chickens well, then he will have eggs to harvest, and the better your chicken, the better eggs you will get. If a farmer has developed a special skill to make his chicken produce golden eggs, then the golden eggs should be his rewards. On the contrary, if the farmer cannot rear his chickens well, then he gets only sick or even dead chickens. He can forget about having eggs to eat.

    There is a Chinese saying that people need food to sustain their lives, while the nation is built upon its people. Our leaders and civil servants have to work very hard

Column: 573

to earn their rewards. In Singapore, to become political leaders by itself is a sacrifice. Like doctors and teachers, the political leaders too make their own sacrifices. We should remunerate them well so that they would dedicate themselves to serving the nation and the people, without having to worry about providing for their families and their children. We often say that for lovers in love, they can survive on water and fresh air only. But how long can they survive? If we want our horses to run well, we must feed them well. How can you deny the horses of their feeds, yet expect them to gallop well? We should not inhibit the able and talented people to earn the rewards which they truly deserve. If they are good, pay them handsomely to commensurate with what they are worth.

    In an open society like Singapore, we should permit "adding flowers to brocade". As a unionist, I feel that while practising "adding flowers to brocade", we should not forget also to "send hot charcoal to the needy during snowy weather". The Government must try and do its best to upgrade the low-income and low-skilled workers so that they too would have the opportunity to upgrade themselves and have a share in the fruits of our economic success. They should be given the necessary assistance in time of need. More importantly, we must ensure that children of every Singaporean, irrespective of their family background, should be given the equal starting point, to receive good education, so that children from the lower-income group will also have the opportunity to get out of the poverty trap.

    There is a widening income gap among the top earners and bottom earners. There is this V-shape going up all the time. But this is not the problem. The key is whether the Government-employer-employee tripartitism can continuously work together to level up the "V", that is, to continuously push up the bottom line of our incomes.

    This morning, we conducted a dialogue session with our trade union leaders. All

Column: 574

the leaders raised their hands in support of this salary revision. So long as the Government can implement the principles, that is, to ensure that the less fortunate are properly looked after, in other words, we must have a good government so that we can attract investments and create more jobs for the people in Singapore, then we will have a good and stable working environment. The trade unions will support this salary revision.

    The trade unionists also agree with building the bonus system into the scheme. The AUPE representative hoped that the PSD will further enhance its transparency in the evaluation of public sector employees, especially those who have become trade union leaders. If possible, they will ensure that these trade unionists will not suffer under the scheme. I hope the Government, in revising the salaries of the public sector, will also expedite the work redesign and re-engineering in the public sector so as to further enhance the efficiency of the public service. I hope that the Government will benchmark the bonuses and other incentive awards with our GDP and other development indicators. They must also take into account the social indicators and standard of living of the lower-income group. What we want is a public service that cares, one that does not sacrifice the "human touch" for efficiency.

    The Senior Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no new arguments for the salary increases. They are obvious. They have been debated thoroughly but it is a popular issue which hits a popular imagination and it is not the norm in other countries to pay the market rate for the job. We have decided to do this and we know - I know and the prime minister knows - that wherever we go, we are greatly envied because they would like to do likewise. They just do not have the political strength.

    The events of the last five years, since the debate on ministerial salaries working out this formula, have only shown that the formula is a practical method. Otherwise in a fast-changing globalised economy - we would be repeatedly debating the need for salary revisions. Instead, we are now

Column: 575

fine-tuning the formula from the average of the top four earners to the top eight earners, in six professions.

    I have grappled with this problem for over 30 years from 1959 to 1990. I had argued this question of ministerial salaries when I was in the opposition in 1955/56, 45 years ago. I then urged the chief minister of the day, David Marshall, to be realistic. His monthly salary then was a princely sum of $3,500 when as a leading lawyer he was making $10,000 to $20,000 a month. I recommended a realistic pay, appropriate to his earnings. But he did not have the political strength to do it and he left it at $3,500. So it remained until I developed sufficient political standing to be able to tackle the question and raise ministerial salaries in the 1970s when the economy had taken off.

    Allow me to recount briefly how we managed in the last 40 years since 1959 so that you will understand where did we start, how have we arrived at where we are. As I have said, the first Cabinet was unusual because it consisted of men who had been drawn together by the forces of history. We were young men in our 30s and 40s, who had been through the sufferings of the war and the Japanese Occupation. And we were tempered by that experience. We wanted independence, and were strongly driven to change the economy and our society. My colleagues were outstanding men, a core group that stayed together from the 1950s to the 1980s, when they retired. They provided Singapore with 30 years of stability, solid growth and finally a transformed society.

    But during that period, every few years I came to this House to revise their salaries to catch up with the fast growth economy and the ever higher salaries in the private sector. As we raced ahead and became part of the global economy, the salaries of our top people have been pulled up by those of their counterparts in the advanced countries and vice versa for those in the lower ranges. This trend is not likely to be reversed, unless we go into decline, in which case, the highly-trained and highly-skilled will leave, accelerating

Column: 576

our fall. Of course, there is no extrapolation to its logical conclusion, as sometimes it would stabilise and plateau, because you cannot have a society which keeps on diverging. You can see from the protests in the developed countries - in America, now in France - that they also are protesting against a globalised economy because their lower end and their middle end earners are hurt by the export of industries, services and jobs; and they are really working against the interest of the developing world that needs these industries and jobs. So I advised the Prime Minister, and finally persuaded him to take this formula of an automatic adjustment to Parliament. The earnings of our top earners will continue to go up with the growth of our economy and so must ministerial salaries. This is a very strong trend.

    Let me give the growth in the last 10 years: average of the top 24 in six professions in 1989 (which is for 1990 income tax) was $1 million. Five years later, in 1994 it became $1.4 million, an increase of over a third. In 1999, it was $2.5 million, an increase of three-quarters, just in the last 10 years. So had we not had this formula, the prime minister would be faced with the awful dilemma of taking the 1994 salary and saying, "Can we revise it by 76%?" There are lawyers and doctors in this House - Shanmugam, Davinder Singh, Dr Michael Lim. They are in the private sector and they can confirm by how much the earnings of top lawyers and top doctors in the private sector have gone up in the last five years.

    In tandem with ministerial salaries, and the ministers form the benchmark, are the salaries of those in the higher echelons in the public service, and they are absolutely crucial officers of the State. Without good men occupying these positions, we would be unable to maintain our present standards - the Chief Justice, judges, attorney-general, auditor-general, accountant-general, permanent secretaries, CEOs of statutory boards.

    When we took over in 1959, we inherited a civil service recruited by the British with very few locals whom they

Column: 577

picked from the best of a small pool of local talent. And it has been one unending process of improvisation and adjustment ever since. For years, we could not get good lawyers to be judges, because the disproportionate earnings in the private sector which they have to give up to become a judge make it unrealistic. Only after 1990, when we had made radical salary revisions, and implemented them, has there been a full panoply of High Court judges. And it is an unending struggle now between the private sector, which includes multi-national legal corporations in Singapore, and the attorney-general's office and the legal service to compete for top talent.

    Let me now explain how we have done it in this chamber. To self-renew, MPs and ministers, besides the civil servants, we had to recruit at every election able younger people. For ministers, I persuaded, and my colleagues too, able academics with PhDs and professionals to run as MPs, then appointed them as ministers. Many did not make it. The attrition rate was high. These scholars had good minds and the ability to marshal facts and figures, and to present them. But they did not have that quality necessary for a minister - "judgement" - making a decision, the right decision, on the basis of complex and incomplete data. You cannot wait until you have got all the facts in and then decide. It is a moving situation. You have to decide where the trend is, what should we do. So I cast around with my colleagues and tried out successful men, never mind whether they got PhDs or not, but whether they had succeeded in the real world, men who have been successful in their professions and business and in their own fields. The results were better.

    Some of my ministers were very good at judging people. Hon Sui Sen, who was one of our best civil servants, permanent secretary, head of Economic Development Board, and later on I persuaded him to become an MP and then finance minister.

    He recommended several, among them people whom he had worked with - Goh

Column: 578

Chok Tong, S Dhanabalan, Tony Tan. They were three heavyweight ministers. We did not know that when we started. We recruited them in the 1970s, but we knew them only in the 1980s. Each year, we also selected 20 to 30 (later we increased it to 100 to 120) of our best students for scholarships to study in the best universities and bonded them to serve the government for eight years. Parents were poorer then, and scholarships were few. So we had the pick of the crop. And it is from that generation of the 1960s and 70s that we have today the present leaders of the civil service and the statutory boards, and quite a number of ministers, scholars and SAF scholars.

    But since the middle-80s, especially in the 90s, our economic conditions changed and social attitudes altered. Now scholarships are numerous and commonplace. I read the Straits Times supplement on scholarships. Hundreds of them every year, because they had seen how we had succeeded - the private sector, the banks, even foreign multi-nationals in Singapore. So the Straits Times devotes a whole supplement to the scholarships on offer, describing, tabulating and comparing them in detail. Statutory boards, GLCs, all the big banks, major companies, like NatSteel, MNCs like Exxon Mobil, KPMG and American Insurance (AIA), they all give scholarships. They are all chasing a limited pool of scarce talent. Moreover, many parents now earn enough to send their children abroad to the best universities and do the subjects of their choice and have their children sign no bond, except to the father and mother, who would agree to whatever they want to do. This has changed the whole system of early recruitment and nurturing and career development of the best for higher appointments. For the last few years, the government and statutory boards no longer have the pick of the crop. That means 10, 15 years down the road, we may not have the same quality at the top echelon.

    Hon Sui Sen recognised these changed circumstances and the altered values of our young. So he persuaded me in the 1970s to abandon this handcuffing of

Column: 579

government officers by their pensions. We were losing, he said, too many good top men who are quite prepared to give up their pensions because they were attracted to lucrative careers in the private sector. So if we did not pay them pension, we could up their salary and compete.

    I was uneasy because we were departing from an age-old system. The British ran an empire for 200 years based on lifetime employment in the government service. But Hon Sui Sen himself had spent his whole life in government service and, at the end, he told me, "Look at my pension!" It was a pittance because inflation plus growth meant a pension was worth little. And he was convinced, and finally convinced me, that younger officers no longer considered their pensions a strong pull factor when deciding whether to stay or to leave. They wanted to be paid their worth immediately and so wanted to go on CPF.

    After much hesitation and reflection, I accepted the change and agreed to abandon pensions in favour of CPF. This led to the next series of other changes where salaries have to be regularly adjusted to match their counterparts in the private sector, or we would end up with the second and third best. It is a continuous series of exercises. In the old system, the British recruited straight from the universities; whether you are a law graduate, doctor, accountant, surveyor, architect, they all have similar salary scales. We inherited that. We carried that on. But it was unrelated to reality. Nobody can predict which profession would be the high flying profession when it comes to maturity. Today it's the law. Tomorrow, it could be something else. At one time, the architects in the building boom had the best returns. So we now have decided, as a result of abolishing pensions, that we have to go with the rate for the market in that profession.

    We have new multi-faceted problems, because the global environment has changed and the best, our best whom we send abroad, are being recruited by top MNCs, also chasing talent and prepared to pay off their bonds. What is

Column: 580

$200,000-$300,000 when you can get a good mind already proven? You can watch his school record, you can watch his college record, you can see his capabilities in argument, in presentation, and you have a ready-made winner. Whether he is a big winner or a small winner, it does not matter. But you know this is first league.

    Let me now take you to how we are now placed. The present team in the government was selected and had worked with the old guards long before 1990. The selection started in the 1960s was not very successful because, as I said, we did not know how to spot who would make a good minister. So we chose people who sympathised with our views, and had good minds. But they lacked the quality of making the right decisions. We started to succeed only in the 1970s, after 10 years of error. And in 1972, I persuaded Ong Teng Cheong, then an architect, to give up his lucrative practice to join us. He took several years to wind up his practice first. He had commitments. Then 1976, Goh Chok Tong, S. Dhanabalan, and 1979, Tony Tan, and so it went on. There were many others. But, as I said, the attrition rate was still considerable. And at one time, we were so short of ministers to hold big ministries, that I persuaded two senior civil servants, top men, proven administrative ability, to contest elections and become ministers - Howe Yoon Chong, who was head of civil service, to become minister for defence, and Teh Cheang Wan, head of HDB, to become minister for national development. So it was an unending quest for the right man to put in the job.

    It takes many years for a person to be tried and tested as a minister, and to develop that judgement and trust. Every cabinet has its core members of the team, goal shooters and goalkeepers. Not all 11 players can have the same star quality. And it is the prerogative of the prime minister to pick his men and, having picked his men, it is his responsibility to get them jell into a team and, as a team, to deliver. I have grappled with this problem. And were it possible, I would have liked to pay the ministers the way football clubs

Column: 581

pay their players. When you have a star player and you change clubs, hundreds of millions of pounds change hands. Could I do it? I would cause so much public discomfiture for the other ministers who are not goal scorers, that team would soon be unable to function as a team. So a certain balance must be kept, solidarity of the team and recognition by the captain that he is a scorer and he is a first-class goalkeeper. Somehow, you have got to get them to share not only the glory but also the remuneration.

    My core members for 25 years, they are well known to the public - Goh Keng Swee, S. Rajaratnam, Hon Sui Sen, Lim Kim San. Prime Minister Goh's core team must be obvious to all those who have watched how his government has performed, who have scored the goals, or have prevented them from being shot into our goal. I leave you to judge. But the point is that all the present cabinet members, including Lim Hng Kiang and Teo Chee Hean, were selected before 1990, before I stepped down. And since then, only three had made it to ministers of state - Peter Chen, Lim Swee Say, David Lim. The last intake of MPs was the highest average we ever had. But there is a difference between a good player and a Pele. That is what we have to look for, a striker. If the present team does not get more good men to join them in the next election in 2002, there will be a hiatus down the road.

    Good government did not happen by doing things naturally in Singapore. It was a thorough and meticulous process of selection and testing. Finally, I learned how the big MNCs did it in America, using psychologists and psychiatrists to recruit and to test before promotion. And we became better also at assessing character. The ability is simple to judge, but the character element is very difficult. But we have assembled together the best persons available and willing. And there is no alternative team, or group of people outside the government, who can replace this present team. I say this without wanting to discourage those who are outside. There

Column: 582

are some probably star players outside, but you have got to form a team and work as a team. If this government should fall, standards of government would go down, because from the very start in 1959, Singapore has had a government which is led by ministers, not by civil servants. The permanent secretaries do not settle policy. They do not innovate. It is the ministers who strike out. It was Goh Keng Swee who started the Economic Development Board; Hon Sui Sen started NOL; SIA, DBS, so many things. They are creative men. It is the opposite of the Japanese system, where top civil servants shape policy. Therefore, if Singapore does not have high calibre ministers, our performance will degrade and our economic growth will stumble and social problems will increase.

    That we have adequate salaries for ministers removes only one of the factors that stand in the way of recruiting talent. Since the last revision to this formula, the prime minister has tried to get many from the private sector to join - top bankers, top CEOs. He ended up only with one - Peter Chen from Shell. Why did the others decline? Some have moved on and become venture capitalists. Because they are bright enough and shrewd enough to see, "Look, I am 40-plus. If I join you, I will be asked to stay on and on and on, if I am successful. If I am not, I am out. By that time, I have lost my connections." Some declined because they sized up the ministers and decided they may not quite measure up. So it is a difficult task. It removes only one obstacle, but not an insignificant factor.

    Politically, it is not possible for any minister, or any MP, or any person to say at the outset that he would not have taken on the task of being a minister if he knew he would not be adequately compensated. But what he would do is, do it for a short term and then excuse himself. I can say this because I have been at it for over 40 years and anyway I am approaching the end of my career. So I can tell you the blunt truth. That period of revolutionary change that threw up people with deep convictions and overpowering motivations is over. That is a fact. We are in an

Column: 583

era of high growth with fortunes being made by the enterprising, whether in a dot.com company or in finance or fund management, or in the professions. And the whole social climate has changed.

    I was looking through the latest Forbes magazine which I have got by courtesy of SIA because I am a frequent flyer. One whole copy lists out all the billionaires in the world with short descriptions of how they became what they are. I am quite sure they sell a few hundreds, if not a few thousand copies in Singapore. So all our top minds are reading and saying, "Surely he can do it, why not I try?" So we have a qualitative change in aspirations. And it affects the old guards too. Some of them meet me and say, "Look at my pension. This is what we are worth." So I looked at them and I said, "But that is the rules we made." They said, "Yes." So from time to time, I persuade the prime minister. I said, "Give the pensioners a bonus because we are doing well. But for them, we would not be doing well." But many of them, if I were to go back and ask them all again, and they knew the progress that Singapore would make, they would tell me, "You carry on. I will stay out." This is the real world. We are not talking of a hypothetical situation. These are real people who are going through a tremendous global revolution in values. You open up Fortune magazine, what is it all about? They also have their list of billionaires.

    Perhaps, if I were a young man of 35 or even 45, I will pause and ask myself, "Why not? Is it so difficult? Somebody else can do this job." But the plain fact is that very few people can do this job. I was explaining to the party secretary of Shenzhen when it was getting started in the 1980s, I said, "You have to be satisfied to run a system that enables many millionaires to flourish, and you are not a millionaire. And if you can do that, then you can succeed. But if you see the millions being made and you want to join in those millions, you will fail. The whole system will collapse." That is the problem. Look around and ask yourself: why has it failed? Because your authority to sign or not to sign a licence decides whether you

Column: 584

will make him a millionaire or a billionaire or not, so why not make yourself one incidentally? It is not very difficult.

    In many countries, like America, people take on a job for a short period and then they go out to the private sector - where having served their country is a valuable addition to their bio-data, apart from the important connections that they will have. You look at one of the most successful American treasury secretaries since World War II, Robert Rubin - (Goldman Sachs, chairman) gave it up. For six years the market knew that they had a professional and a very able professional, and they had confidence in him. The boom in the Clinton years is partly due to him and to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed. But he wanted to leave after the first term. He was persuaded to stay on. He stayed on another 11/2 years and now he is co-chairman of the Citigroup.

    Let me point out how long it takes to get an MP to learn to be a minister and have the public recognise him as such, especially when he is not a natural crowd puller or a mobiliser. There are two kinds of ministers in Singapore - the doer and the mobiliser. The ideal is to be able to do both.

    When Mah Bow Tan contested against Chiam See Tong in Potong Pasir, you would not believe it, in 1980, he lost. Because you stand in a crowd, watch two chaps performing, and say, "I think this chap looks reasonable. He is bright, energetic," and so they voted for him. But I happened to know Mah Bow Tan and I knew his career. He had worked closely with me when we tried to help the Singapore Monitor get started to compete against the Straits Times and halfway through he told me, "Look, we can't. It will lose because of the grip of the Straits Times on all sources of news. They've bought out all the agencies, all the cartoons, everything. You cannot beat them." I decided that this man has judgement. So we fielded him in 1984 and only after another 10 years, now 16 years, that people have a different impression of him. They know that he is competent and effective. Look at the ministries that he

Column: 585

has handled. So the prime minister now gives him National Development.

    Next, you take Teo Chee Hean. He stood in the by-election in Marine Parade in 1992 - tall, lean, lanky, a bit gawky - as against Dr Chee Soon Juan, voluble, exuberant. If it was not a GRC, one-to-one, he may well have lost. Because what was the basis for judging? A short note about his CV and you see the physical person and you judge him on what he says at a few rallies. But eight years later, from the things he has done, from the difficult problems he is setting out to solve, people recognise that this is a thinking man and a very serious man who gets things done and he is going to get the schools up to a different level, and the teachers too. They have seen the quality in the man, the depth of his commitment and that he can deliver.

    You take Lim Boon Heng, a Colombo Plan scholar, did naval architecture in the University of Newcastle. He worked in NOL in 1971 but because Goh Chok Tong had worked with him, he knew that this man can do things. He persuaded him to stand for election as MP in 1980, then sent him to NTUC to work with the secretary-general, Ong Teng Cheong. The NTUC is not a glamour sector. No great addition to your bio-data that will get you into a higher job. Maybe you can become a human resource or a trade union contact man. But from a good government point of view, NTUC is absolutely crucial because your policies have got to be sensitive to the large mass of the semi-skilled and the unskilled and somehow you must be able to craft your solutions so that they also have a place under the sun. Quietly, he built up rapport with union leaders and workers and won their confidence by his sincerity. Eleven years later, in 1991, he became senior minister of state for trade and industry, to test his decision-making power as an administrator. Then in 1993, he went back to NTUC as secretary-general and minister without portfolio in the PMO. When a difficult measure like cutting the CPF by 10% was necessary two years ago, he

Column: 586

played a major part in persuading workers and union leaders to agree to this rational but emotionally very difficult cut. The point I want to make simply is this. It takes many years of quiet work to build up relationships and establish trust. Those in the NTUC doing this job, they are a crucial part of good government.

    As I have said, one flaw of the democratic system is that voters do not have a proper assessment of the real person behind a first-time candidate - his character, his steadfastness, his trustworthiness. They only know him after several years and it is true of ministers, of the Speaker and of every MP, including the opposition. Both Chiam See Tong and Low Thia Khiang have been re-elected because their electorate has seen them as consistent and steady and are prepared to continue to have them represent them. Hence, it is important that MPs are suitably remunerated. People need time to gauge and assess who has the qualities best suited for what jobs that can make Singapore grow and thrive. The danger for Singapore is one of sudden change, a new school term with new pupils, new prefects, new head prefect, and a new school principal. Many things can go awry. And I cannot over-emphasise the importance of continuity.

    The virtuous cycle that we have established, which the prime minister spoke about earlier today, is a cycle of good government making for high growth and social progress, leading to the re-election of good government, leading to the ability to renew that good government by recruiting more good men to continue the work. That cycle could be broken. If it does, it will probably never be re-established. You just look at the travail of the LDP in Japan. After 40 years in office, in the last decade, they have suffered from decreasing voter support. One factor which will help prevent that happening in Singapore is to have elections without money politics - no money to win elections, even to fight elections, and to pay ministers, judges, permanent secretaries, CEOs of companies and all those in the Government two-thirds of the market rate for the job. The issue is a

Column: 587

simple one, whether the public sector should adopt the market rate. Big corporations give their top CEO share options, worth multi-millions, to attract the best. When they fail, they are out. Proctor & Gamble had two bad quarters, and the CEO resigned, and they looked for another one.

are really risking our future. It is a world-wide disease and especially endemic in Asia, and we can be easily striken by it. Only constant vigilance has kept it down.

    Let me then turn to the last point and the most controversial. I think it is understood that Singaporeans want a Government of good quality. But quality is not all. The very fact that for the two years of the crisis there was a freeze recognises the sensitivity. So, are the changes that are being suggested enough? In some ways, I am for the changes because they actually try to make it a fairer system, 48 people rather than 24, the median rather than the average. But is that enough of a change? Again, I have to ask the question: what is the mischief?

Five years ago when we argued the principle of benchmarking salaries, we had the assumption that the whole economy was going to go up, that everyone would benefit from good Government and what Singapore will deliver for them. When we talked about this again in the crisis years, we all felt affected. Of course, looking back now, we know that those in the very top still prospered. But the general sentiment was that we were in it together as one nation, one society.

This new context brings out not just the market forces which everyone has emphasised, but the question the Prime Minister and the Senior Minister put to us: what do we do as a society? Can we keep diverging as a society? The Senior Minister who spoke before me said no. We can hope there must be some balancing point. He pointed to global forces which then speak out against this continuing divergence. In this context, we have to ask ourselves whether this new policy will help or hurt us. This is why the public and this House have been engaged in debate about the true level of

Column: 594

the bottom 10% in Singapore, whether it is $133 per month or $530 per month, if we take out the jobless people. Are those still too low? We have, in this context, to ask ourselves whether this new formula is really going to continue to help bind the society together in a deeper way. We respect that doctors must earn a good living. In Singapore, they do. But if your doctor tells you that he is interested in your fees and not your health, you know you are in trouble. Everyone thinks that lawyers are in for the money, which is why there are all these jokes about lawyers and sharks, paying each other mutual professional respect.

much the CEO is paid as compared to the bottom worker. Sometimes it is a multiple of 20, 30, 40 or more. through Government scholarships or academic excellence. The more it remains a closed club, it would invite resentment and criticism.
